article_name: Looking to put up 40,000 small cells from 4,000 in next 5 years: CloudExtel CEO
meta_text: We are looking at our base growing from 4000 small cells to 40000 small cell sites in the next five years. That's a conservative projection, obviously, we believe and hope that we can do a lot more than that, but that will require well over 400-500 crores for us to really pull that off, and that's where the opportunity to scale and build a substantial network," said Bajaj.

article_name: Small cells to play a major role in Indian telcos' network expansion: CloudExtel
meta_text: The small cell sites that exist today across the country are addressing the challenges being faced by the 4G network. And certainly, you will continue to see a lot of growth driven even just by 4G, before 5G starts becoming mainstream. And so even in the next few years, we continue to see small cells playing a major role in how network expansion and network investments are going to be done by all three of the telecom operators," Bajaj said.

article_name: CloudExtel appoints former Vodafone Idea exec Deepak Saxena as SVP of wireline services
meta_text: We are delighted to welcome Deepak Saxena as Senior Vice President, Wireline Services. He will be a part of the core leadership team of CloudExtel and will be responsible for scaling and accelerating NaaS for Telecom Service Providers (TSPs), Internet Service Providers (ISPs), data centres, and prominent OTT players," the firm said in an update on linkedin.

Telecom infrastructure sharing may spur gear sharing too, experts say
meta_text: The current scenario could change with Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (Trai) recommending creating a separate category under the unified license for Digital Connectivity Infrastructure Provider (DCIP) authorisation. "...the proposed DCIP authorisation holder may create both active and passive digital connectivity infrastructure and share it with other TSPs and has to pay no license fee to the government," Trai said in its recommendations last month.
